comments.body:
We could let the fixer when it works, but removing it also works.
```suggestion
      fix: suggestion ?
        (fixer) => fixer.replaceText(node, suggestion) :
        undefined,
    });
```
That doesn't replace the single offending character. It replaces the text of the entire node. If you have `console.log("»");` in your code, it will replace your entire file with `"`.

If we go through the trouble of fixing it so that it just replaces the offending character, it will still be broken because it will change `console.log("»");` to `console.log(""");` which is a syntax error. We'd basically only want to apply the suggestions in comments. Given how infrequently this rule comes up, I don't think spending time perfecting auto-fix on it is a good use of time (but I won't stop anyone else who wants to do it--I'm just unlikely to do it myself).
